sentence: You would have to go all the way back to the third quarter of 2013 to find the last time Adobe Systems (ADBE), which offers a broad range of software and services used by professionals (including Photoshop), missed the Street’s earnings estimates.
Since then it has been seamless execution by the cloud marketing software giant, which doesn’t get nearly the credit it deserves as a top-notch executioner.
The company’s investors, meanwhile, who have gotten rich since the 2013 hiccup, have watched their stock quietly rise almost 170% during that span.
And with the company set to report second quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after Tuesday’s closing bell, analysts have begun to take notice.
Just in the last three months, eleven analysts offering a 12 month price target for ADBE have raised their price objective above $140, including a high estimate of $160.00, according to TipRanks.
But with the consensus price target being $146, which is just 4% above Adobe’s current price, these shares, which have already risen 36% year to date, could fly much higher.
Not only has the San Jose, Calif.-based company beaten the Street’s EPS estimates by an average of more than 4 cents per share, during that span, revenue has grown by more than 20% annually.

Thanks to the management’s continuous innovation in the Creative Cloud and Marketing Cloud businesses, Adobe has also shown the confidence to raise revenue outlook during the past figure earnings beats.
Notably, this is despite the company facing stiff competition from the likes of Salesforce (CRM) and Oracle (ORCL).
All told, it would be a mistake to part with Adobe shares now.
For the quarter that ended May, Wall Street expects Adobe to report 95 cents per share on revenue of $1.73 billion, translating to year-over-year growth of 34% and 24%, respectively.
For the full year ending November, earnings are expected to rise 31% year over year to $3.95 per share, while full-year revenue of $7.17 billion would climb 22% year over year.

The breathtaking top- and bottom-line forecasts are the result of the payoff Adobe continues to realize from the strategic investments the company has made in the business, including shifting its business from software sold in a box to a subscription model.
As such, Adobe’s Creative business, which has Marketing Cloud customers such as Verizon (VZ), UPS (UPS), Pandora (P), is seeing growth acceleration in Creative Cloud subscriptions.
And in terms of its enterprise Creative Cloud offering, the company’s decision to shift enterprise customers to its Enterprise Term License Agreements is also paying off.

With consistent top and bottom-line growth combined with strong Creative Cloud momentum, Adobe stock -- currently at around $140 -- should reach $170 in the next twelve months, delivering 20% returns.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
